#### Definition

The *scale convolution* of two functions $s(t)$ and $r(t)$, also known
as their *logarithmic convolution* is defined as the function
$$s \ast_l r(t) = r \ast_l s(t) = \int_0^\infty s(\frac{t}{a})r(a) \frac{da}{a}$$
when this quantity exists.

#### Results

The logarithmic convolution can be related to the ordinary convolution
by changing the variable from $t$ to $v = \log t$: $$\begin{aligned}
s \ast_l r(t) & = & \int_0^\infty s(\frac{t}{a})r(a) \frac{da}{a} = 
                \int_{-\infty}^\infty s(\frac{t}{e^u}) r(e^u) du \\
 & = & \int_{-\infty}^\infty s(e^{\log t - u})r(e^u) du\end{aligned}$$
Define $f(v) = s(e^v)$ and $g(v) = r(e^v)$ and let $v = \log t$, then
$$s \ast_l r(v) = f \ast g(v) = g \ast f(v) = r \ast_l s(v).$$
